Fig. 1 H2-TPR patterns of the calcined catalysts. In this paper, an efficient nickel-cobalt bimetallic catalyst was designed and developed for catalytic hydrogenation of furfural, one of the biomass platform products, to 2-methylfuran, a high value-added chemicals. The NiCo-MgAlO catalysts were synthesized by the co-precipitation method and characterized by H2-TPR, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption analysis, O2-TPO, FAL-TPD, NH3-TPD, TEM and other methods. These results revealed that the Ni/Co ratio, solvent, reaction temperature, pressure, time, and, most importantly, the catalyst reduction conditions had a major impact on this reaction. 100% of furfural conversion and 92.3% of 2-MF selectivity were achieved over the Ni10Co5-MgAlO-3h catalyst with its Ni/Co molar ratio of 2 when employed 2-butanol was the solvent. It could maintain high activity even after using it several times. The bimetallic Ni10Co5-MgAlO catalyst owned homogeneous composition of Ni-Co alloy nanoparticles and more middle-acid sites than the monometallic Ni10-MgAlO catalyst, which might promote C-O bond cleavage and improve 2-MF selectivity due to its oxygen affinity. The high yield of 2-methylfuran from furfural may be due to the synergistic effects of the metal sites and the acid sites on the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst's surface. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Furfural 2-methylfuran Bimetallic catalyst Hydrotalcite Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The ever-increasing consumption of fossil fuels has hastened the degradation of environmental contamination as a result of rapid economic expansion. Nowadays, renewable biomass has emerged as a possible alternative for the development of the modern chemical industry since it can be effectively converted into a variety of chemicals as the only renewable carbon source [1]. For example, furfural (FAL), one essential biomass platform chemical, could be prepared industrially from xylan-type hemicellulose by acid hydrolysis and dehydration [2–4]. Currently, furfural production has been predicted to exceed 1 million tons each year. Most importantly, it can be transformed to various high-value derivatives such as cyclopentanol (CPL), furan (FU), furfuryl alcohol (FOL), tetrahydrofuran (THFU), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL), and 2-methylfuran (2-MF) via catalytic hydrogenation of the C=C or C=O bonds of furfural [5–8]. Among them, 2-methylfuran is a raw material for insecticides and antimalarials. It also has a high octane number and better combustion efficiency, making it a potential fuel substitute in industrial production [9]. Traditionally, the industrial production of 2-MF from FAL involves the selective hydrodeoxygenation of FAL via intermediate FOL over the Cu-Cr catalysts [10]. However, chromium compounds can cause serious environmental problems [11]. As a result, considerable work has been undertaken in developing non-Cr-containing catalysts for the hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF [12]. For example, noble metal catalysts like Ir, Ru and Pt showed excellent activity. Date reported a 95% yield of 2-MF from furfural over a 5% Ir/AC catalyst, which could be the best result of the noble metal catalysts in the literature [13]. In Wang et al.’ s work, an 80.8 % yield of 2-MF was obtained over the carbon-supported Pt-Co catalyst at 180 °C with an H2-to-furfural ratio of 100 because the bimetallic catalyst can effectively suppress the decarburization and over-hydrogenation of C=C bond of FAL [14]. In comparison to these noble metal catalysts, the transition metal catalysts such as Co, Fe, Cu and Ni demonstrated superior activity for FAL hydrogenation using either high-pressure exogenous hydrogen or a liquid hydrogen donor as the hydrogen source [12,15–17]. However, they exhibited different product distributions, mainly related to the adsorption mode of furfural, i.e., through the furan ring or the side chains or both, on these metals [18,19]. For example, on the surface of Cu (111), furfural prefers to adsorb via carbonyl O with the h1(O)-aldehyde conformation, and subsequently, H attacks the O atom to reduce the carbonyl group, then producing FOL as the main product [20]. While for the Ni-based catalysts, furfural tends to form h2(C, O)-aldehyde and h1(C)-alcy surface configuration [21], on which hydrogenation, as well as ring-open and decarbonylation reactions, are active because of the strong interaction of Ni metal with furan ring, resulting in a higher hydrogenation activity and a lower 2-MF selectivity. Therefore, the high yield of 2-MF usually was not achieved on the monometallic Ni or Cu-based catalysts. To improve the hydrodeoxygenation capability of these Ni or Cu-based catalysts, one effective strategy is to modify them with a second metal [22]. For instance, the addition of Fe could reduce the decarbonylation activity of NiFe and promote C-O hydrogenolysis, resulting in higher 2-MF selectivity [14,23]. The bimetallic Cu-Ni [24] and Cu-Co [15] catalysts also performed better than the monometallic Cu or Ni catalysts in the hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF by inhibiting the formation of the h1(C)-alcy adsorption configuration. Furthermore, Jiang et al. [25] found that the yield of 2-MF followed the order of CoPtPt(111) > FePtPt(111) > NiPtPt(111) > CuPtPt(111), which was in accordance with the oxophilicity of the second metal. Typically, the oxophilic surfaces should bind more strongly to the carbonyl group's O. In the hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF, metallic Co with strong oxophilicity leads to the largest tilted configuration of furfural, which favors the breaking of the C-O bond and the selective formation of 2-MF [14,19,26]. The surface acid sites, in addition to the oxophilic metal, would also make a significant contribution to the breakage of the C-O band [22,27,28]. Therefore, the optimal combination of metal and acids species during FAL hydrogenation is critical for the effective production of 2-MF. It is worth noting that the layer double hydroxides (LDHs) and their derived mixed metal oxides (MMOs) could be widely used as heterogeneous catalysts for upgrading biomass and derived molecules [29]. MMOs have high stability and a large specific surface area with tunable acid of the surface in both nature and strength [30,31]. Kong et al. [32] reported that the amounts of the surface Ni and acid sites on the Ni-Al-based hydrotalcite catalysts were carefully modulated by changing the annealing temperatures. The concentration of the surface acid sites of the NiMgAl catalysts increased gradually from 400 to 600°C but decreased by 70% to 800 °C. In this work, we prepared a Co-Ni bimetallic catalyst supported on MgAl-mixed metal oxide (denoted as CoNi-MgAlO) for FAL conversion into 2-MF under an H2 atmosphere and investigated how to modulate the synergic catalysis between the bimetallic Ni-Co and medium-strong acid sites to obtain a high 2-MF selectivity. The effects of the reaction conditions such as hydrogen pressure, reaction temperature, time, catalyst amounts, and solvent types on catalytic activity are also discussed here. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ni-based bimetallic samples were synthesized by the co-precipitation method, in which the Al/Mg ratio was 1:3, and the weight percentage of Ni-M (M was the second metal) was 15%. The aqueous solutions containing Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(Ac)2·4H2O (or Cu(NO3)2·6H2O, Fe(NO3)3.9H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O)with a total concentration of metallic ions of 1.5 mol/L were used in a typical preparation process. Then, under vigorous stirring, the mixed aqueous solution and a solution containing 1.5 mol/L NaOH and Na2CO3 (1:1) were added dropwise into deionized water, where NaOH and Na2CO3 were two times the sum of the moles of all divalent metal ions. The obtained suspension was aged at 70 °C for 40 min before being transferred to a hydrothermal kettle at 120 °C for roughly 16 h, washed three times with ethanol, dried at 120 °C, and finally calcined in air at 700 °C for 5 h. Finally, this powder was reduced at 750 °C under an atmosphere of 5% H2 (50 mL/min), denoted as NixMy-MgAlO, M was Co, Cu, Fe, Zn; x, y respectively represent the mass percentage of Ni or M in the catalyst. In addition, the Ni10Co5-MgAlO catalysts with different reduction time were denoted as NiCo-MgAlO-H, and H represented the reduction time (3, 6, 9 and 15 h). After that, the monometallic Ni-MgAlO and Co-MgAlO catalysts were prepared in the same way and reduced at 750 °C for 3 h, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The sample structure and crystal form analysis was carried out on a Bruker D8 advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα ray radiation at 30 kV and 10 mA and a scanning angle (2θ) ranging from 5°to 85°at the scanning rate of 5°/min. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of these samples were investigated on the ASAP 2020 supplied by Micrometric. Before N2 adsorption, the samples were degassed at 250 °C for 12 h and then tested at -196 °C. A high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) was conducted in JEM-2010TEM with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. H2 temperature-programed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on the II 2920 chemical adsorption equipment supplied by Micrometric. The 50 mg catalyst was put into the reactor, kept at 200 °C under an Argon atmosphere for 2 h, and then heated to 1000 °C in a 5% H2/N2 atmosphere. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), performed on Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 too, could be used to observe the acid type and acid strength of the catalyst. Before NH3 was adsorbed, a 50 mg material was pretreated at 400 °C to remove impurities on the surface. It was saturated with NH3 at 50 °C and then purged with Helium gas to remove physically adsorbed NH3. NH3-TPD experiments were subsequently carried out in the Helium flow with a ramp rate of 6 °C/min. O2 temperature-programmed oxidation (O2-TPO) is an effective tool for testing the degree of catalyst reduction. It was also measured by Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. The reduced catalyst was pretreated in argon at 200 °C for 2 h, then cooled to room temperature and heated to 1000 °C in 10% O2/Ar at a heating rate of 10 °C /min. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic hydrogenation reaction of furfural was performed in a 100 mL high-pressure autoclave. In a typical catalytic test, 3.0 g of furfural, 0.5 g catalyst and 20 mL of 2-butanol solvent were introduced into the autoclave. The air in the autoclave was replaced by H2 three times, then the reactor was filled with the desired hydrogen pressure and was heated to the desired temperature to start the reaction. After 6 h of reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. The obtained mixture was further filtered by centrifugation. All the liquid phase products were then collected and analyzed by gas chromatography equipped with a hydrogen flame ion detector and an HP-AL/KCL capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.32 μm). All of the compounds were identified and quantified using cyclohexanone as the internal standard after comparing the retention durations of the respective standards. The selectivity of the major products and the conversion of furfural were calculated as follows: Selectivity ( % ) = m o l e o f t h e p r o d u c t p r o d u c e d m o l e o f f u r f u r a l c o n v e r t e d × 100 Conversion ( % ) = m o l e o f f u r f u r a l c o n v e r t e d m o l e o f f u r f u r a l f e d × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The results of H2-TPR for the calcined NiO-MgAlO, CoOx-MgAlO and NiO-CoOx-MgAlO catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 . As shown in it, the reduction of CoOx and NiO over the three samples took place between 700 and 850 °C, suggesting the strong interaction between the active metals (Co and Ni) and the MgO-Al2O3 support. In other words, it can be attributed to the reduction of Cox+ and Ni2+ from the spinel structures of Mg(Ni, Cu, Al)O. Based on the total integrated areas of the reduction peaks, the H2 consumption amount of NiO-CoOx-MgAlO was higher than that of NiO-MgAlO and CoOx-MgAlO, indicating the reduction of both Ni and Co species. Moreover, it could be seen that the reducibility of the metal species increased significantly when both Ni and Co were loaded in the support. In particular, for the Co species, its reduction peak migrated from 930 to 810 °C, suggesting a strong interaction between Ni and Co in the NiCo-MgAlO catalyst. The addition of Co also significantly facilitated the dispersion of the Ni particles, as will be confirmed by the XRD pattern later (Fig. 2 ). Therefore, to achieve synergistic catalysis between the metal sites and the acid sites of the catalyst, the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst was reduced at 750 °C, and a more careful control (e.g., reduction time from 3 to 15 h, reduction atmosphere and flow rate) over the structural transformation of the NiO-CoOx/MgAlO catalysts was carried out. The XRD patterns of the four NiCo-MgAlO catalysts with different reduction time were presented in Fig. 2. The unreduced sample displayed three broad peaks at 2θ = 36.88°, 43.04° and 62.41°, attributed to a mixture of MgO and the spinel structure (MgAl2O4, NiAl2O4, CoAl2O4) as indexed in the literature [33]. After the catalyst was reduced at the H2/N2 atmosphere, three new peaks at 44.38°, 51.73° and 76.41°, assigned to the metallic phase of Co and Ni, appeared. The peak intensity of metallic Ni and Co increased gradually as the reduction time was increased from 3 to 12 h. The particle size of metal particles based on the Scherrer equation increases from 14.1 to 23.1 nm, indicating a gradual reduction of cobalt and nickel oxide from the spinel structure to metallic Co and Ni in the catalyst. Noted that the (200) diffraction peak of the reduced NiCo-MgAlO catalysts fell between its corresponding values of the monometallic Ni-MgAlO and Co-MgAlO sample (Fig. 2), confirming the appearance of the Ni-Co alloy. The reflections of the Ni-Co alloy shifted slightly to higher 2θ values with the increasing of the reduction time, implying the formation of the Ni-Co alloys with different Ni0/Co0 ratios in the studied catalyst. The Ni0/Co0 ratios of the Ni-Co alloys were calculated from the (200) spacings by Vegard's law and presented in Table 1 . It can be noticed that the longer the reduction time, the higher the Ni0/Co0 ratios, indicating the different reducibility of Ni and Co in the NiCo-MgAlO catalyst. When the reduction time reached 15 h, the Ni0/Co0 ratio of the NiCo-MgAlO-15h catalyst was 3.6, suggesting that Ni was gradually segregated into the surface of the catalysts to generate a Ni-rich Ni-Co alloy. In order to quantify the average reduction degree of these NiCo-MgAlO catalysts, O2-TPO experiments were performed and shown in Fig. 3 . The TPO profile of the monometallic Ni-MgAlO-3h sample exhibited one oxygen consumption peak due to the oxidation of the Ni0 phase in NiO-MgAlO. All four bimetallic NiCo-MgAlO catalysts showed a broad oxidation profile, ascribed to the oxidation of metallic Co and Ni from the catalyst's surface. A closer look at Fig. 3 revealed that the total integrated region of the oxidation peaks increased gradually with the reduction time increasing from 3 to 15 h. Correspondingly, the average reduction degree of metallic Ni and Co in total active metal species increased from 33.1 to 88.5% (Table 1, assuming that Ni0 + 1/2O2→NiO, Co0 + 3/2O2→1/2Co2O3). Furthermore, the maximum peaks of the TPO profile shifted significantly toward lower temperatures from NiCo-MgAlO-3h to NiCo-MgAlO-15h, and the Ni-MgAlO-3h sample showed the lowest oxygen consumption, indicating the reduction-improving effect of the Ni-Co alloy, consistent with the H2-TPR results in Fig. 1. Besides that, the FAL-TPD experiments were used to calculate the adsorption amount of reactant furfural over the various samples [12,25]. All four NiCo/MgAlO catalysts showed a similar FAL desorption peak, as shown in Fig. 4 . The desorption amount of FAL was highest on the NiCo/MgAlO-15h catalyst. The FAL adsorption from NiCo/MgAlO-3h to NiCo/MgAlO-15h with an enhancement of metallic Ni and Co amount displayed a linear relationship, suggesting the Ni-Co alloy was one of the essential factors governing the efficiency of the catalysts as the active site. The fitting results, on the other hand, indicated that the total amounts of metallic Ni and Co in the studied catalysts improved with reduction time, which is compatible with O2-TPO experiments. The structure and distribution of metal species in the studied materials were investigated by TEM characterization (Fig. 5 ). It is observed that Ni nanoparticles of the Ni-MgAlO catalyst were uniformly dispersed, having a similar size of 18 nm (Fig. 5a). The HRTEM image in Fig. 5b further indicated that the selected particle's interplanar spacing was 0.200 nm, which corresponded to the (111) plane spacing of Ni nanoparticles. In contrast, the HRTEM images of the NiCo-MgAlO catalysts with reduction time ranging from 3 to 15 h showed that the interplanar spacing of the selected particle varied from 0.204 to 0.202 nm, which seems to be between the (111) plane of metal Ni (0.200 nm) and Co (0.214 nm), suggesting the formation of bimetallic Ni-Co alloy. Furthermore, these NiCo-MgAlO catalysts with varying reduction time exhibited smaller particle sizes, implying that the incorporation of Co could facilitate the dispersion of the Ni nanoparticles. As displayed in Fig. 5a and b, the mean size of metal nanoparticles decreased from 18 nm (Fig. 5a) to 11 nm (Fig. 5b) after Co loading and then enhanced from 11 to 17 nm (Fig. 5e) when the reduction time increased from 3 to 15 h, which is consistent with the results of XRD analysis. The electronic properties of Ni and Co species in the studied catalysts were further revealed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The XPS results of Ni2p and Co2p spectra are shown in Fig. 6 a and b. The binding energies for Ni 2p3/2 at 852.4 and 869.9 eV were ascribed to Ni0 and Ni2+ (NiAl2O4) on the catalyst surface [34,35], respectively, which were the main Ni species in the monometallic Ni-MgAlO catalyst. The binding energies for Co 2p3/2 at 777.7 and 781.1 eV were assigned to Co0 and Co2+ (CoAl2O4) on the catalyst surface [34,36], respectively. It was clear that metallic Co was absent in the monometallic Co-MgAlO catalyst. However, for the bimetallic NiCo-MgAlO catalysts, both metallic Ni and Co appeared and increased with increasing the reduction time, supported by the XRD and O2-TPO results. Additionally, the Co 2p3/2 peaks in the spectra of the four bimetallic NiCo-MgAlO catalysts exhibited slight downshifts compared with Co-MgAlO reference, while the shifts of the Ni 2p3/2 peaks to higher values could be clearly observed. It is thus concluded that a charge was transferred from Ni to Co due to the metallic synergic effects and the formation of the Ni-Co alloy nanoparticles with different chemical compositions caused by the increasing reduction degree. 3.2 Surface acidic property of the NiCo-MgAlO samples The surface acidity of the catalysts is critical in the conversion of furfural to 2-MF, and the NH3-TPD experiment was employed to investigate the surface acidity of the tested samples (Fig. 7 ). Two distinct NH3 desorption peaks were found in Ni-MgAlO, as illustrated in Fig. 7A. The peak in the range of 300–380 °C was identified as the middle acid site, and the other peak centered at 400 °C was associated with the strong acid site. The Co-MgAlO sample also showed two NH3 desorption peaks: 80–120 °C and 200–300 °C, respectively, identified as the weak and another middle acid site. It was noticed that the desorption peak of the middle acid sites was dominant for Ni-MgAlO and Co-MgAlO, with metallic Ni and Co species absent because of their low reduction degree. In contrast, the concentration of the medium acid sites was significantly reduced in the presence of metallic Ni and Co species for the bimetallic NiCo-MgAlO-9h and NiCo/MgAlO-15h catalysts with a higher reduction degree. Besides that, it should be remarked that the concentration of the medium acid sites increased nearly monotonously with the reduction degree of the NiCo-MgAlO catalysts (Fig. 7B). Interestingly, the medium acid amount of Ni-MgAlO with a higher Ni2+ content (1.13 mmol/g) was lower than that of NiCo/MgAlO-3h (1.33 mmol/g). It suggested that the middle acid sites of the catalyst surface mainly originated from two species, Ni2+ and Co2+, in the NiCo-MgAlO catalysts. The formation of the Ni−O−Al and Co−O−Al bond resulted in a severely distorted octahedral Ni−O and Co−O microenvironment, and the coordinatively unsaturated Ni−O and Co−O structure enabled the formation of numerous medium acid sites [37,38]. All in all, the Ni2+ and Co2+ contents enhanced from NiCo-MgAlO-15h to NiCo-MgAlO-3h, and the total acid concentration increased gradually, which could explain the differences in the acidity amounts of the four NiCo-MgAlO catalyst surfaces. 3.3 Catalytic performance The catalytic activities of various monometallic and bimetallic catalysts were evaluated by the experiments of hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF. For comparison, several bimetallic Ni10M5-MgAlO (M= Fe, Zn, Cu, Co) and NixCoy-MgAlO catalysts with varying Ni/Co mole ratios were also synthesized using identical procedures. Fig. S1 shows the XRD patterns of these Ni-based bimetallic catalysts, and the Ni-Cu, Ni-Fe, and Ni-Zn alloys were detected over these catalysts, respectively. Fig. S2 displayed the results of a N2 adsorption-desorption analysis used to investigate the textural features of these catalysts. It showed a type IV isotherm with H4 hysteresis loops, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials. Table S1 shows the specific surface areas, pore diameters, and pore volumes of different Ni-based catalysts. The specific surface areas of all samples were higher than 100 m2/g, attributed to the rich pore structures of the mixed metal oxides derived from hydrotalcite. When these catalysts were loaded with the bimetallic Ni-Cu, Ni-Fe, Ni-Co and Ni-Zn components, the specific surface areas increased significantly compared with the monometallic Ni-MgAlO and Co-MgAlO catalysts. It was due to the smaller particle sizes and more uniform dispersions of these bimetallic catalysts. First, the reaction parameters were carefully optimized, and FAL hydrogenation was performed in 2-butanol at 3 MPa H2 and 220 °C with a stirring rate of 400 rpm. The results of FAL hydrogenation over the Ni-based bimetallic catalysts are presented in Table 2 . From it, the monometallic Ni10-MgAlO catalyst exhibited a high conversion of FAL but a low selectivity to 2-MF of 49.7% (entry 1). The bimetallic Ni10Fe5-MgAlO catalyst had higher 2-MF selectivity than Ni10-MgAlO, while FOL and THFOL were prominent over the bimetallic Ni10Cu5-MgAlO and Ni10Zn5-MgAlO catalysts (entry 3-4). In the hydrogenation of FAL, Ni typically has high reactivity in either C=O or C=C, transforming FAL into other products rather than 2MF. Co, on the other hand, is less active in the saturation of C=O bond [27,39]. When Co was added as the second metal, the bimetallic Ni10Co5-MgAlO-3h catalyst showed the highest 2-MF selectivity of 92.1% (entry 6). The intermediate FOL of the C=O partial hydrogenation increased with the Ni/Co ratios increasing in the bimetallic Ni10Co5-MgAlO catalysts (entries 6–9). Notably, in the case of Ni10Co5-MgAlO-15h with the Ni0/Co0 ratio of 3.6, the high selectivity of 74.7 % to FOL was obtained. While the referenced bimetallic Ni5Co10-MgAlO and Ni7.5Co7.5-MgAlO catalysts with the lower Ni0/Co0 ratios (Table S2) gave a high 2-MF selectivity of more than 88%, indicating that Co was responsible for the selective hydrodeoxygenation of C=O in furfural [25,34]. Furthermore, despite the absence of metallic Co, the surface of the Ni10-MgAlO catalyst generated more 2-MF than FOL compared to Ni10Co5-MgAlO-15h, implying that the metallic Ni or Co as the active sites was not the only factor controlling the catalyst efficiency. In this work, the yield of 2-MF from Ni10Co5-MgAlO-15h to Ni10Co5-MgAlO-3h increased with increasing medium acid concentration (Fig. 8 A), whereas the yield of FOL was closely tied to the concentration of metal sites on the catalyst surface (Fig. 8B). These results revealed that the synergistic catalysis between bimetallic Ni-Co alloy and medium acid sites played a significant role in the hydrogenation reaction of FAL to 2-MF. To better understand the role of metal and acid site cooperativity in total hydrogenation of FAL, the turnover frequency for hydrogenation of FAL (TOF C=O, Table S3) and hydrodeoxygenation of FOL (TOF C-O, Table S4) were measured over NiCo-MgAlO catalysts, respectively. TOFC=O and TOFC-O were based on the rate of FOL and 2-MF formation per number of exposed surface metal availability after reduction, respectively (both FAL and FOL conversions were less than 30% by reducing the amount of catalyst and reaction time). It can be observed that the TOF values for the hydrogenation of FAL to FOL were significantly higher than those for the hydrodeoxygenation of FOL to 2-MF among all NiCo-MgAlO catalysts (Fig. 9 A), indicating that the latter was the rate-determining step for the hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF. Furthermore, the TOFC=O values followed the sequence of NiCo-MgAlO-3h > NiCo-MgAlO-6h > NiCo-MgAlO-9h > NiCo-MgAlO-12h, which corresponded to a decrease in the concentration of the middle acid sites for each catalyst (Fig. 9B), implying that the acidic sites on the catalyst surface had a beneficial effect on the activities of the Ni-Co catalytic step, significantly speeding the formation rates of FOL and 2-MF. It is noteworthy that for NiCo-MgAlO-12h, which had a high amount of metal but a low concentration of the middle acid sites, on the one hand, the value of TOFC=O could still reach 311.5 h−1, indicating that both the active metal and the acid sites on the surface promoted the hydrogenation activation of the carbonyl C=O bond during the hydrogenation of FAL. On the other hand, the value of TOFC-O on NiCo-MgAlO-12h was lower than 20 h−1, suggesting that the acid sites mainly serve to undergo the hydrodeoxygenation of FOL to 2-MF. Additional tests were carried out to evaluate the effect of acid sites on the hydrodeoxygenation of FOL to 2-MF by adding pyridine to the process to poison acid sites. The catalytic data (Fig. 10 A) pointed out that an equimolar amount of pyridine and furfural decreased the TOFC-O values after 2 h of reaction at 160 °C for all the catalysts. In particular, this decay was more pronounced for both NiCo-MgAlO-3h and NiCo-MgAlO-6h, which owned the high concentration of the middle acid sites, indicating the catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF was strongly influenced by the acidic sites on the catalyst's surface. Interestingly, for the reference Ni-MgAlO catalyst, the TOF values at both 220 and 160 °C were smaller than those of the NiCo-MgAlO-12h catalyst despite the latter having a lower concentration of the middle acid sites, again indicating that the bimetallic NiCo-MgAlO catalysts gave higher 2-MF yields for the hydrogenation of FAL compared to the monometallic Ni-MgAlO when the intrinsic rates of these catalysts were considered. More importantly, after an equimolar amount of pyridine and furfural was added to the reaction, the selectivity of 2-MF on Ni-MgAlO catalysts decreased, with intermediate THFOL as the main product (Fig. 10B). However, for all the bimetallic NiCo-MgAlO catalysts, the selectivity of 2-MF reached 100%, indicating that Ni-Co alloy nanoparticles could bind more strongly with O of the C-O band and further promote C-O hydrodeoxygenation of FOL to 2-MF. In addition, when the acidic sites of the catalysts were poisoned, if the TOFC-O values were related to the Co content of the bimetallic NiCo-MgAlO catalysts, as shown in Fig. 10B, it was found that NiCo-MgAlO-9h with the highest Co content had the highest TOFC-O value of 14 h−1. These results further suggested that the hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF was sensitive to not only the surface acidity of the catalysts but also to the formation of the Ni-Co alloys. In other words, the modification of Co to Ni can modulate the adsorption conformation of FOL over the Ni-based catalysts and accelerate the hydrodeoxygenation of FOL to 2-MF. The effects of the reaction time on the hydrogenation of FAL over Ni10Co5-MgAlO-3h at 220 °C in a 2-butanol solvent were investigated. In Fig. 11 A, it could be found that the conversion of furfural reached 100% after 6 h. FOL was the main product in the early 2 h, and then it decreased with reaction time gradually. The selectivity of 2-MF increased monotonously during the investigated reaction time and reached up to 92% after 6 h. The catalyst also showed a low selectivity toward furan, indicating the low reactivity for decarbonylation of FAL. In Fig. 11B, it could be seen that reaction temperature also affected FAL conversion and product distribution. As the reaction temperatures ramped from 160 to 180 °C, FAL conversion increased from 65 to 95%, while FOL selectivity decreased sharply from 30% to less than 1%. When the temperature was raised to 220 °C, the selectivity of several by-products such as THFOL and FU, gradually decreased to a minimum of 6.8% and 1.1%, respectively, while 2-MF selectivity reached a maximum of 92.1 %. The selectivity of 2-MF was also significantly enhanced when increasing H2 pressure from 1MPa to 3MPa (Fig. 11C). More than 35% FOL selectivity was obtained at the low H2 pressure of 1MPa, and high H2 pressure could facilitate the hydrogenolysis of the C–O bond in FOL to 2-MF. Additionally, the effects of reaction solvent were explored over Ni10Co5-MgAlO-3h, as shown in Fig. 11d. It could be seen that 2-butanol was the best solvent in the hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF (Fig. 11D). Furfural conversion was only 26% in the absence of a solvent. FU and FOL selectivity were 22.6% and 30.4%, respectively. The non-polar solvent of dodecane showed the poorest performance in that the conversion of FAL was less than 10%, which indicated that the non-polar solvent had an inhibitory effect on the hydrogenation reaction of furfural. It may be due to the extremely low solubility of furfural in dodecane, which suppressed the sufficient contact of the reactants with hydrogen during the reaction. By contrast, the conversion of furfural increased dramatically when polar solvents were used. It is because they can participate in the hydrogenation reaction as proton donors. The yield of 2-MF in isopropanol and 2-butanol reached 90.1% and 92.3%, respectively. However, when methanol and ethanol were chosen as the alcohol solvents under the same reaction conditions, the main product was FOL, not 2-MF. For example, a 92% selectivity of FOL was obtained in methanol. Interestingly, although isobutanol, 1-butanol, and 2-butanol have moderate proton donating ability, 2-butanol has a relatively strong polarity and was more favorable for FAL hydrogenation. The effects of alcohol hydrogen donors on catalytic transfer hydrogenation of furfural have also been observed over α-MoC [40], Fe [41], and Cu-based [42,43] catalysts, and employing alcohols as a solvent on these catalysts can further mediate the selectivity of the products in the furfural hydrogenation . The reusability of the NiCo-MgAlO-3h catalyst was investigated under optimal reaction conditions, and the result is shown in Fig. 12 A. The catalyst was filtered from the reaction products after each run, then washed with ethanol and carefully dried. After four recycle evaluations, a minor decrease in 2-MF selectivity was observed, which could be attributed to a small loss and a slight deactivation of the catalyst during the recycling operation. The mean size of the metal particles on the spent catalyst after four times usage was 11.7 nm (Fig. 12B), nearly the same as that of the fresh catalyst, and no phase changes could be observed according to the results of XRD characterization (Fig. 12C). These findings showed that the prepared catalyst had excellent stability. In the fifth cycle (Fig. 12A), when adding the fresh catalyst to the initial weight of the recycled catalysts, more than 90% yield of 2-MF could be obtained again. Furthermore, the Ni and Co contents in the fresh catalyst were 9.75% and 4.39%, respectively, as analyzed by ICP-AES. After four reuses, it dropped to 9.47% and 4.02% for Ni and Co, respectively. Therefore, the small loss of catalyst and the slight leaching of Ni and Co into the liquid phase during the recycling process may be responsible for the drop in 2-MF yield. The slight deactivation phenomenon, however, should not change the conclusion of this work, and more research into improving the stability of the bimetallic Ni-Co catalyst is considered necessary. Reaction condition: Furfural 3 g, Catalyst 0.5 g, 220 °C, 3 MPa, 400 r, 6 h, 2-butanol 20 ml; * adding about 0.2 g fresh catalyst; (B) TEM of the spent catalysts after four times usage; (C) XRD patterns of the fresh and spent Ni10Co5-MgAlO-3h catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this study, the selective hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF was carried out using the Mg-Al oxides supported Co-Ni bimetallic catalysts. The FAL conversion of 100% and the 2-MF selectivity of 92.1% could be obtained after 6 h at 220 °C and 3 MPa H2 over the catalyst. It also could maintain a good activity even after using it several times. The addition of Co in the Ni10Co5-MgAlO catalysts promoted the dispersion of Ni. Furthermore, the formation of Ni-Co alloy particles on the catalyst surfaces contributed to modulating the adsorption conformation of FOL on Ni-based catalysts and accelerating the hydrodeoxygenation of FOL to 2-MF. The distribution of the metal sites and acid sites on the Ni10Co5-MgAlO catalyst surface was also significantly affected by the reduction conditions. The acid sites on the catalyst surface were further reduced as the catalyst reduction degree increased, which was unfavorable to the activation of the C-O bond and the hydrogenation of FOL, reducing the selectivity of 2-MF. The high selectivity in catalytic hydrogenation of FAL to 2-MF is due to the synergistic effects of metal and acid sites on the catalyst surface. As a result, these highly efficient Ni-Co alloy catalysts may draw great interest in upgrading biomass-derived furfural and guide the synthesis of new non-precious metal bimetallic catalysts for hydrogenation catalytic processes. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, an efficient nickel-cobalt bimetallic catalyst was designed and developed for catalytic hydrogenation of furfural, one of the biomass platform products, to 2-methylfuran, a high value-added chemicals. The NiCo-MgAlO catalysts were synthesized by the co-precipitation method and characterized by H2-TPR, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption analysis, O2-TPO, FAL-TPD, NH3-TPD, TEM and other methods. These results revealed that the Ni/Co ratio, solvent, reaction temperature, pressure, time, and, most importantly, the catalyst reduction conditions had a major impact on this reaction. 100% of furfural conversion and 92.3% of 2-MF selectivity were achieved over the Ni10Co5-MgAlO-3h catalyst with its Ni/Co molar ratio of 2 when employed 2-butanol was the solvent. It could maintain high activity even after using it several times. The bimetallic Ni10Co5-MgAlO catalyst owned homogeneous composition of Ni-Co alloy nanoparticles and more middle-acid sites than the monometallic Ni10-MgAlO catalyst, which might promote C-O bond cleavage and improve 2-MF selectivity due to its oxygen affinity. The high yield of 2-methylfuran from furfural may be due to the synergistic effects of the metal sites and the acid sites on the Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst's surface.
coredata.dc:title: The catalytic hydrogenation of furfural to 2-methylfuran over the Mg-Al oxides supported Co-Ni bimetallic catalysts
